in_text.heading: 21. Midline catheter tip position and catheter-related complications in antimicrobial therapy: A multi-center randomized controlled trial
in_text.statement:
(Zhao L et al. Int J Nurs Stud. 2023)
Study author(s)
Zhao L, Fan X, Zhao L, et al.
Study design (level of evidence)
Randomized controlled trial (Level 2)
Study objective
5
To provide evidence for selecting MC tip
positions for safe use in antimicrobial
therapy.
Publication
Int J Nurs Stud. 2023
DOI: 10.1016/j.ijnurstu.2023.104476
Study location
China
Study Length
5 months (September 2020 - January 2021)

in_text.heading: Study protocol
in_text.statement:
Evaluation indicators and judgment criteria were
incidence of catheter-related complications and
indwelling catheter duration.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: Longest dwell time recorded was of 131 days.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: Prophylactic anticoagulation showed reduced CT trend but was not statistically significant.

in_text.heading: Key points
in_text.statement: MC tips placed in the subclavian or axillary vein of the chest wall had the lowest complication rates.

in_text.heading: Study conclusions
in_text.statement:
Placing midline catheter tips in the subclavian or axillary vein significantly reduces catheter-
related complications during antimicrobial therapy.

in_text.heading: 22. Comparing incidence of thrombosis in PICC and midlines and evaluating the role of anticoagulation, site of insertion, and risk factors
in_text.statement:
(Zohourian H et al. J Assoc Vasc Access. 2019)
Study author(s)
Zohourian H, Schaubschlager T, Phan L,
et al.
Study design (level of evidence)
Retrospective cohort study (Level
Study objective
To evaluate previously proposed risk factors
associated with increased rate of CT and to
form an objective clinical prediction score to
aid clinicians in distinguishing high-risk
patients.
Publication
J Assoc Vasc Access. 2019
DOI: 10.1016/j.java.2018.29.004
Study location
United States
Study Length
1 year (January 1, 2016 - December 31, 2016)

in_text.heading: Study protocol
in_text.statement:
Inclusion criteria: Adult patients who underwent
either a PICC or midline catheter placement
between January 1 and December 31, 2016.

in_text.heading: Study protocol
in_text.statement:
The means or frequencies of potential catheter-
related thrombosis (CT) risk factors were compared
between cases and controls.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: The insertion site, whether basilic, brachial, or cephalic vein, did not significantly affect the risk of thrombosis.

in_text.heading: 23. Midline venous catheters as an alternative to central line catheter placement: a product evaluation
in_text.statement:
(Car A et al. Br J Nurs. 2021)
Study author(s)
Carr A, Green JR, Benish E, et al.
3
Study design (level of evidence)
Prospective observational study
(Level 3)
Study objective
To evaluate the clinical performance of the
Powerwand® midline catheter
Publication
Br J Nurs. 2021
DOI: 10.12968/bjon.2021.30.8.S10
Study location
United States
Study Length
4 months (September 2018 - December 2018)

in_text.heading: Study protocol
in_text.statement:
In infants, the Powerwand  was typically inserted in
the lower leg or upper arm, while in toddlers and
older children, it was placed in the forearm or upper
arm.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement:
Patients were spared an average of 12 vascular access attempts, during their hospitalization, when
Powerwand was used.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement:
On average, the use of these catheters prevented average 6.1 PVC reinsertions and 6.3 blood draw sticks per
patient. In terms of cost, each Powerwand  catheter cost $170.25, compared to $32.55 per PVC. This resulted
in an overall cost saving of $2,892.45 due to the reduction in PVC use.

in_text.heading: Key points
in_text.statement:
The Powerwand  provides additional benefits from other midline catheters available related to the
product composition and insertion technique

in_text.heading: Study conclusions
in_text.statement:
The Powerwand midline catheter offers a safe, durable, and cost-effective alternative to
CVCs and PVCs, reducing complications and improving vascular access outcomes across
patient populations.

in_text.heading: 24. Optimizing vascular-access device decision-making in the era of midline catheters
in_text.statement:
(Cawcutt KA et al. Infect Control Hosp Epidemiol. 2019)
Study author(s)
Cawcutt KA, Hankins RJ, Micheels TA,
et al.
Publication
Infect Control Hosp Epidemiol. 2019
DOI: 10.12968/bjon.2021.30.8.S10
Study design (level of evidence)
Narrative review (Level 6)
Study objective
To guide clinicians in selecting the most
appropriate vascular access device (VAD)
and to address risks, benefits, and
complications associated with various VADs.
Study location
United States
Study Length
NA

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement:
Midlines do not reach central veins, reducing risk of pneumothorax, cardiac arrhythmias, and central venous
stenosis.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: Vancomycin and other medications previously considered vesicants are increasingly safe via midline.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: Mechanical complications (e.g., pain, edema, occlusion) occur at rates between 2.6%–11.5%.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: Thrombosis risk is generally lower than PICCs, especially in non-ICU settings.

in_text.heading: 25. Recommendations for the use of vascular access in the COVID-19 patients: an Italian perspective
in_text.statement:
(Pittiruti M et al. Crit Care. 2020)
Study author(s)
Pittiruti M, Pinelli F
Publication
Crit Care. 2020
DOI: 10.1186/s13054-020-02997-1
Study design (level of evidence)
Consensus recommendations (Level
6)
Study objective
To recommend safe and effective vascular
access strategies for COVID-19 patients.
Study location
Italy
Study Length
NA

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: Midlines reduce the number of insertions needed, leading to resource savings & lower exposure risks.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: Ultrasound-guided insertion is strongly recommended for midlines.

in_text.heading: Study findings
in_text.statement: No radiologic confirmation is needed for tip placement in midlines
